title: 'I've never heard such baloney' Farage EXPLODES at LBC caller for claiming UK needs EU
text:
'I've never heard such baloney' Farage EXPLODES at LBC caller for claiming UK needs EU 'I've never heard such baloney' Farage EXPLODES at LBC caller for claiming UK needs EU NIGEL FARAGE was left fuming on LBC after a caller claimed the UK was better off financially by being a member of the European Union. PUBLISHED: 10:48, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 | UPDATED: 10:53, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 
The former Ukip leader failed to hide his annoyance, as the man accused Farage of presenting his listeners with unreliable facts and offered his own "accurate and fact-checkable" statistics. 
Seething against the anti-EU MEP, the LBC caller claimed freedom of movement generates £28million a day for the UK economy. 
Having none of it, Farage exploded into a rant as he lambasted the caller for using the Remain camp’s old arguments to make a point. 
The LBC host roared: "I've never heard such baloney or such spurious statistics in my life. We do not need to be members of a political union to buy and sell goods from each other. GETTY • LBC Farage was left fuming on LBC after a caller claimed the UK was better off inside the EU Related articles EU minister demands May listen to SNP as Scotland 'wants' to REMAIN 
“Unlike your spurious nonsense, what I have quoted you is the Government pink book statistics which shows we pay a net 10 billion pounds every single year as a membership fee to this union. 
“You can argue, if you like, that is not a big sum of money compared to many other things but I tell you what, with that money you could build a really good, big brand new District General Hospital every single week in this country.” 
During the Tuesday night programme, Nigel Farage also took a swipe at Jean-Claude Juncker after the Eurocrat outrageously warned Britain faced a “very hefty” bill for Brexit . 
The European Commission President insisted the decision to abandon the red-tape obsessed bloc would not come “at a discount or at zero cost”. I've never heard such baloney or such spurious statistics in my life Nigel Farage 
Raging against Mr Juncker, urged the country to “stand up” to the demands. 
“Like all divorces, this needs to be a fair deal for both sides, we need to have a proper rational assessment of our costs, assets and liabilities,” Mr Farage said. 
“But by asking for 50 billion sterling after we leave - Jean Claude-Juncker is taking the mickey!” 
Farage continued: “We need to stand up and start getting tough, Mrs May needs to say ‘we’re going to stop paying into this budget until you sit down round the table with us so we can work out a proper long term deal’. 
“I want us to be fair, but to quote a former prime minister, we want our money back!” Brexit: Which parts of the UK had the majority vote? Fri, February 17, 2017 Much of the North East of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union including Sunderland, Gateshead, Darlington, Durham, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Stockton, Redcar and Cleveland, North Tyneside and South Tyneside, and Northumberland. Newcastle was the only borough to vote to remain. Getty Images 1 of 8 GREAT YARMOUTH: The town of Great Yarmouth on the East Coast of England voted by 72% to leave the European Union. 
Mr Juncker’s stark warning to the UK comes after the European Union shamelessly threatened the UK with a £500billion (€600bn) Brexit divorce bill in January – ten times the figure initially expected. 
Late last year it was widely reported Eurocrats were planning on slapping the UK with a £50billion (€60billion) exit bill as punishment for voting to abandon Brussels in the June referendum. 
However, Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's top Brexit negotiator, has now said he expects Britain to cough up over £500bn to the European Union as it extricates itself from Brussels. 
Mr Verhofstadt replied: “What I know is the outstanding commitments now and before Britain will leave the European Union will in total be around €600billion (£513billion). That’s the reality and you can find in the accounts of the EU.” Related articles
